1.title: Precursor to chords: Intervals
1.point1: Intervals refer to the distance between two notes. This distance affects how the two notes sound together.
1.point2: Intervals are said to be made of a number of half and/or whole steps

2.title: Chords
2.point1: Chords are combinations of three (or four) notes with specific intervals between each note, which create a certain signature sound
2.point2: Chords are created from a combination of two different intervals: Minor Thirds and Major Thirds

subtopic1.topic: A minor third consists of 3 half steps

subtopic2.topic: A major third consists of 4 half steps)

3.title: Chords (Cont.)
3.point1: There are four different types of chords: Major, Minor, Augmented, and Diminished
3.point2: We will mostly cover major & minor chords today

subtopic1.topic: Major chords are created from a major chord (in green), followed by a minor chord (in purple)

subtopic2.topic: Minor Chords are created from a minor chord (in purple), followed by a major chord (in green)

4.title: Quick aside: Keys
4.point1: The key defines what scale underlies/defines the song
subpoint1: For a note to be "diatonic" to a key means that the note belongs in the scale
The first note of a key/scale is known as the "root"
4.point2: There are two general types of Keys: Major and Minor
subpoint2: Major scales are defined by the interval pattern of: W W H W W W H (Play)
Minor scales are defined by the interval pattern of: W H W W H W W (Play)
4.point3: So why do keys matter in our learning?
subpoint3: The same progression can sound slightly different based on the song's keyâ€”focus on the music's overall vibe/shape, rather than a direct 1-to-1 comparison
